insights.summary:
## What's Trending
*   **Authentic Personal Journeys:** Authors share their entrepreneurial origin stories, career milestones, and personal struggles to build deep connection and inspire.
*   **Actionable Business & Career Advice:** Posts provide concrete strategies, lessons learned, and practical tips for building businesses, navigating competition, or protecting SMBs.
*   **Community & DEI Advocacy:** Recognition of individual achievements is leveraged to celebrate and uplift broader communities, particularly women in cybersecurity, fostering inclusivity.
*   **Strategic Insights & Thought Leadership:** Experts share their perspective on market dynamics, product development, and the future of the cybersecurity industry.

## Recurring Angles
*   **Inspirational Storytelling:** Weaving personal history and passion into professional narratives to convey expertise and resilience.
*   **Educational Value:** Offering practical advice, demystifying complex topics, or sharing strategic business insights for specific audiences (e.g., SMBs, startups).
*   **Gratitude and Collaboration:** Acknowledging collective effort, thanking nominators/partners, and celebrating success as a community endeavor.
*   **Direct Engagement & Calls to Action:** Posing questions to the audience, inviting comments, or directing them to external resources like videos, podcasts, or platforms.

## Why These Posts Worked
*   **Relatable & Vulnerable Narratives:** Sharing personal journeys and challenges makes the content highly engaging and resonates with aspirations and struggles of many professionals.
*   **Clear Value & Actionable Takeaways:** Posts offer tangible benefits, whether it's inspiration, strategic lessons, or practical security steps, making them highly shareable and useful.
*   **Strong Hooks & Engaging Openings:** Compelling headlines and opening lines (e.g., "At 17...", "How I beat the competition...") immediately capture attention and drive readership.
*   **Community-Centric Messaging:** Posts that celebrate and empower specific groups within the industry foster strong engagement and a sense of belonging.

ğŸ§  **Trend Label:** Authentic Expert Storytelling

posts_analyzed.author: Sanjay Katkar
posts_analyzed.post_text:
At 17, I wrote my first program in BASIC.
At 18, I was coding in assembly for 8085 chipsets.
At 20, while still in college, I reverse engineered my first computer virus.

That moment changed everything and fighting computer viruses became my passion.

Passion, when combined with dedication and vision, can shape the future.

For me, cybersecurity wasnâ€™t just a career; it was a calling. What started as a fascination with computer viruses turned into a lifelong journey of building solutions that protect millions of users with Quick Heal.

Whether itâ€™s coding, cybersecurity, art, or any craft you love, never underestimate its potential. The world needs people who are deeply passionate about what they do. 

Your hobby could be the foundation of your future business, it all starts with believing in its possibilities.

The key is to refine your skills, explore ways to solve a problem, and share your passion with the world. 

With dedication and the right mindset, your hobby can evolve into a great business.

What passion drives you?
Maybe itâ€™s time to take the next step! ğŸš€

posts_analyzed.author: Jane Fankland MBE
posts_analyzed.post_text:
âœ¨ Honoured Beyond Words â€” Cybersecurity Woman Entrepreneur of the Year (World) âœ¨

Iâ€™m incredibly proud, and deeply humbled, to share that Iâ€™ve been awarded Cybersecurity Woman Entrepreneur of the Year (World) by CEFCYS - Cercle des Femmes de la CyberSÃ©curitÃ©.

What makes this moment even more meaningful is that I wasnâ€™t in Paris to receive the award in person. 

Instead, it was accepted on my behalf by remarkable women â€” leaders in their own right â€” who embody everything this industry needs: courage, collaboration, and unwavering commitment to progress.

There is something beautifully fitting about that.

Because nothing Iâ€™ve built â€” not the companies, not the initiatives, not the scholarships, not the IN Security Movement â€” has ever been done alone. It has always been powered by people who believe in a future where cybersecurity is more inclusive, more innovative, and more human.

To CEFCYS - Cercle des Femmes de la CyberSÃ©curitÃ©, thank you for recognising my work, and for championing women across our industry. Your mission matters, and Iâ€™m proud to stand alongside you.

To every woman in cybersecurity â€” entrepreneur, practitioner, leader, or aspiring professional â€” this award is as much yours as it is mine. 

Keep going. Keep showing up. Keep claiming your space. The world needs your brilliance now more than ever.

ğŸ’› Hereâ€™s to building, lifting, and leading â€” together.

Finally, to the person (or people) who nominated me â€” thank you. Your belief, your support, and your quiet advocacy behind the scenes mean more than you know. I appreciate you, and Iâ€™m TRULY grateful.

I'm sharing a snippet of the full award ceremony where CEFCYS - Cercle des Femmes de la CyberSÃ©curitÃ© are revealing the winner of this award but you can watch the whole ceremony here:

Thank you to Dr Ludmila Morozova-Buss for calling me to let me know I'd won. I was collecting my daughter from work, so was able to share the news immediately with her! ğŸ˜Š

PS. Tomorrow I'm at Black Hat Executive Summit (EU) in London, and then back there again on Thursday to meet my IN Security scholarship winners. Hope to see you if you're going.

posts_analyzed.author: Jane Fankland MBE
posts_analyzed.post_text:
How can small business owners move from simply being aware of cyber threats to actively defending against them? 

It starts with practical, actionable steps. 

Now youâ€™ve heard me say cybersecurity needs to be made less complex, well this month, I've partnered again with BT Business to help demystify cybersecurity and empower SMBs to build a stronger defence. 

In this video, I share three essential practices you can implement immediately to protect your business: 

ğŸ”¹ Treat cyberattacks like fire drills and rehearse your response.Â 
ğŸ”¹ Empower your people to be your first line of defence.Â 
ğŸ”¹ Know your digital footprint and take steps to secure it. 

Protecting your business is the foundation for growth. 

Watch the video to learn more and head over to BT's Cyber Security Decoded platform to learn more about how to protect your business:

posts_analyzed.author: Sanjay Katkar
posts_analyzed.post_text:
How I beat the competition without 50% of their features. 

Hereâ€™s howÂ notÂ to get stuck in a catch-up game with competitors.

I still remember the early days of Quick Heal. Competing with MNCs like Norton and McAfee felt like David vs. Goliath. They had massive teams and long feature lists and I had neither.

But I had one thing: a deep focus on whatÂ reallyÂ mattered to users. And that changed everything.

ğŸ‘‰Â Lesson: Build for user value, not engineering perfection.

Startups often fall into the trap of building "the right way"; perfect architecture, complete feature sets. But most of the time, that kills speed. And in the startup world,Â speed is survival.

Hereâ€™s what worked for me (and still works today):
1. Focus on the core problem your product solves
2. Make those core features delightful and reliable
3. Donâ€™t chase feature parity, chase user satisfaction
4. Release fast, learn faster
5. Let real-world feedback guide your evolution

While others raced to add features, I obsessed over making core functionality rock-solid and learning from customer feedback that eventually led us to create true differentiators.

This helped Quick Heal grow from a small Indian startup into a global cybersecurity brand used by millions.

Every Quick Heal release had just a few â€œhero features.â€ But they solved user pain so well, even MNCs began copying them.

So ask yourself:
Are you building features just to tick boxes in a comparison sheet, or are you delivering real value based on what your users actually need today?
